About

A question I often get is why I stepped away from medicine. Here’s why:

1. As a natural systems thinker, I excel at creative problem-solving, a skill that doesn’t get much play in clinical medicine, where protocols and guidelines largely govern practice. 

2. I’m not convinced that the way we’ve organized our world—where prosperity is available to only a small fraction of humanity—is at all inevitable, and I’m deeply invested in working towards change on that front.  It’s a focus area that, admittedly, lies outside the scope of medicine.

3. I don’t believe the solution to many challenges in my part of the world, Africa, lies in creating low-cost versions of sleek Global North technologies or deploying clever ad hoc fixes. While those approaches have their place, lasting change requires tackling the complex systems that create and perpetuate poverty. We must re-think the laws and institutions that reinforce global economic inequality——a task that, again, goes well beyond the scope of clinical medicine.

My work now is in global development and is anchored in creating a world where everyone can—and will—do well. At Hagush, we’re making digital technology access universal while also tackling the deeper structural issues that perpetuate global economic inequality.

If we can raise $200,000 by October 26, we have the potential to increase donations this GivingTuesday by tens to hundreds of millions of dollars. Failing to reach this goal means thousands of nonprofits will miss out on critical funding.

As an example, last year GivingTuesday invested $80,000 in a media campaign, which significantly contributed to raising $500 million in additional donations and engaging 2.1 million more people. With an extra $200,000 this year, we can exceed those results and drive even more giving.

We are a temporary action group formed to address an unprecedented crisis: nonprofits are facing severe budget cuts. Our mission is to mobilize a dedicated group of individuals to take immediate, actionable steps to support thousands of nonprofits in need.

This initiative is being led by Catalyst Now, Propel Philanthropy, the Systems Studio, and Robert Roth, PhD. We invite you to join us in this crucial effort.

For those with questions about our projections, we understand they may seem ambitious. The following resources provide deeper insights and data supporting our goals:

What does 'Beyond GDP' look like from a credit rating perspective?

I’ve been following the UN’s #BeyondGDP work closely (https://lnkd.in/enzckj23) and this week I finally tried to bring it into the credit rating conversation.

The UN Secretary-General’s Expert Group is building a new global dashboard of indicators to measure well-being, sustainability, and resilience. It’s a fascinating and important shift, a chance to redefine how we think about progress itself.
Yet every time a government speaks to a credit rating agency or investor, the conversation still begins and ends with the same familiar figures: GDP growth, GDP per capita, debt-to-GDP. This is because it is the shared language that markets understand.

My new Substack essay - The Shared Language Problem - looks at what happens when these two measurement systems meet. Can we design metrics that are meaningful for people and the planet and legible to investors? Or will governments be forced to live between two incompatible scorecards - one that defines progress, and another that defines risk?

You can read it here: https://lnkd.in/eYNw7xrc
